chapter.summary: Describes when to admit a person following an insect bite or sting. It does not discuss the management of anaphylaxis — see the Prodigy topic on Angio-oedema and anaphylaxis for more information on management of anaphylaxis.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 1 month onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Arrange immediate admission to Accident and Emergency for anyone who:
    • Is suspected of having a systemic hypersensitivity or toxic reaction to an insect sting or bite.
      • Depending on the clinical situation, treat urgently as for shock, angio-oedema or anaphylaxis, while awaiting emergency transfer to hospital — for further information, see the CKS topic on Angio-oedema and anaphylaxis.
    • Has had a previous systemic allergic reaction to the same type of bite or sting. 
    • Is severely immunocompromised and have symptoms or signs of an infection.
    • Has been stung on the mouth, throat or tongue and is at risk of airway obstruction.
    • Has ben stung around the eyes and is at risk of compromised vision. 
    • Has cellulitis that is associated with systemic effects or is worsening despite treatment in primary care. For further information on cellulitis, see the CKS topic on Cellulitis - acute.
    • Has a fever or persisting lesions associated with a bite or sting which occurred whilst travelling outside the UK.
    • Has been stung by an unusual insect or one from a tropical or sub-tropical area.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on when to admit a person following an insect bite or sting are based on the guidelines Emergency treatment of anaphylactic reactions: Guidelines for healthcare providers [Working Group of the Resuscitation Council (UK), 2008], Stinging insect hypersensitivity: A practice parameter update 2011 [Golden et al, 2011], Envenomation from Tick Bites and Bee, Wasp and Ant Stings [ANZCOR, 2016] and Insect bites and stings: antimicrobial prescribing [NICE, 2020], and expert opinion in a clinical textbook [Monsel et al, 2016], a factsheet Insect Venom Allergy Factsheet [Anaphylaxis Campaign, 2015] and review articles [DTB, 2012; Przybilla and Rueff, 2012].

Admission for systemic hypersensitivity and toxic reactions
  • In addition to severe reactions, close monitoring is also needed for people with less severe systemic reactions and those responding to treatment as clinical condition can deteriorate rapidly and treatment rebound occur [BMJ Best Practice, 2016].
  • Fatal sting reactions have been associated with delay in administration of adrenaline [Golden et al, 2011].
  • In addition to hypersensitivity reactions, bee and wasp stings may also produce a toxic reactions. Local toxic reactions from venom manifest as burning pain and usually subside within a few hours. Systemic toxic reactions (severe headache, vomiting, diarrhoea and shock) may occur with multiple stings and can be fatal particularly in children [Monsel et al, 2016].
Admission for cellulitis
  • The recommendation on admitting a person with severe or worsening cellulitis due to secondary infection following an insect bite on sting is based on what CKS considered to be good practice and evidence based recommendations in the CKS topic Cellulitis - acute.
